main event: On November 23, 1948, at FurstenFeldbruck, Germany, a USAF Captain (P-80 Pilot) observed an unidentified object in the sky, moving in a southerly direction, turning slightly to the south-east and then further south-east.
interesting points: The object was spotted at 2220 hours and was initially thought to be a reddish star, with estimated speeds between 200 and 500 MPH.
It was observed climbing and circling at altitudes ranging from 27,000 to 10,000 feet, and was confirmed by radar reports.
The report suggested that the object might have been a balloon with a light on it, but the tactics and implied time in sight appeared to be against an astronomical interpretation.
There were no F-80 jets flying on the night of the sighting, and the observer, a USAF Captain, is considered completely reliable.

The incident summary and evaluations from the Project Grudge report categorized different sightings into various probabilities and potential explanations, shedding light on the diversity of observed phenomena.
sighted object: unidentified object moving at high speeds and changing altitude
